ygData.subject: Re: Crawler running with less than configured threads.
ygData.msgSnippet: SEVERE errors always mean something that is likely crawl-fouling/corrupting has occurred. In this case, it appears the SEVERE errors killed the threads in

From: Gordon Mohr <gojomo@...>
Subject: Re: Crawler running with less than configured threads.
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=137285340; y=s4D2EVMZP7utY74WYruaudRZZB3cbFDqlHOecs30LHdR
X-Yahoo-Profile: gojomo

SEVERE errors always mean something that is likely 
crawl-fouling/corrupting has occurred.

In this case, it appears the SEVERE errors killed the threads in which 
they occurred while reading the top URI from their respective queues. At 
the very least the URI in process will not be crawled; it is also likely 
the entire queue it came from is no longer in frontier rotation, and the 
crawl may not checkpoint/terminate clearly. (That's even if other 
threads still appear to be making progress... are they?)

If these errors all happened only *after* checkpoint-resumption, it 
might be possible to find the cause or a workaround, and then again 
resume (more successfully without errors). However, it's also possible 
that these are reflecting earlier latent corruption in the 
earlier-crawl/checkpointed data.

Are any of the instances showing the problem (2,4) the one that had the 
other hung-checkpoint problem? (Do you have any idea what had triggered 
the IO-exceptions that were correlated with those failed/hung checkpoints?)

Did the SEVERE SerializationExceptions occur right after resumption, or 
did they happen over a longer period (perhaps with more occcurences 
since the initial report)?

If for one of the affected instances, you try another resume from the 
exact same checkpoint, do the exact same number of errors occur?

I vaguely recall seeing a similar error when first converting to the 
'Kryo' serialization (for compactness and speed), but believe the error 
at that time was quickly fixed (and no JIRA issue mentions the same 
BufferUnderflowException root cause). Our 'KryoBinding' class creates an 
ObjectBuffer that's supposed to grow as large as necessary (max-size: 
Integer.MAX_VALUE), so it should never be too small (but might trigger 
another kind of failure if it were growing without practical limit).

Do the affected instances (2,4) show any other alert/WARNING/SEVERE log 
output, before or after the checkpoint-resume cycle?

Have you made any customizations to CrawlURI or added/modified objects 
that might be stored inside a CrawlURI?

I don't really know what's happening, but if you have a well-preserved 
checkpoint which can be repeatedly resumed to reproduce the exact same 
flurry of errors, there's a chance more testing (including added logging 
code) can be done to figure out exactly what's going wrong. Whether it's 
fixable in your checkpoints, or only for future crawls, remains to be seen.

- Gordon

On 1/5/12 10:19 AM, David Pane wrote:
> I have been running a 5 instance crawl (instance #0 through #4) since
> 12/23 (Heritrix 3.1.1). I am using 1200 threads on each instance. Each
> machine has 64MB of ram.
>
> I stopped the crawl the other day due to a scheduled server room power
> outage. A restarted the crawl a couple hours ago.
>
> I am now seeing that instance #4 is running with 1190 threads instead of
> 1200. The heritrix_out.log shows these SEVER errors.
>
> Can you advise me on what I should do? It looks like the instance is
> slowly loosing more threads from this error....
>
> It looks like one other instance (instance #2) had one SEVERE error
> similar to these in instnace #4 (SerializationException)
>
> --David
>
